author: oaklandmatt
content:
@everyone I just wanted to express gratitude to you all. This is the only place many of us have – on the internet or otherwise – that is a healthy, supportive, *non-political* community. We're nearly 2000 people and I fucking love browsing the depth and breadth of conversation on here. There's real love for music and creativity and camaraderie, and it brings me immense joy.

So to the newbies and experts, the casual lurkers and Grammy-winning essayists, from the bottom of my heart, thank you all. ❤️

author: BatMeckley
content: Wishing everyone a happy happy holidays, no matter whether you have a Grammy, whether you give great advice or objectively bad takes, whether you’re tall, short, or in between, whether you’re Irish, or from somewhere better, no matter which holiday you celebrate, whether you post here or just lurk to soak up the great information, whether you’re Matt Rad who put this all together or Cian who tries to burn it all down, I love you all and wish health, happiness, and prosperity for you and your families. 💙🎄

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Hey @everyone 

Please post your questions publicly on the Discord rather than DMing people privately

 I get the same questions over and over on DM here, on IG, even on Gearslutz. Which speakers? How should I treat my room? What limiter etc? If I were to answer each one individually it would 

A) Be a huge time suck
B) Deny everyone else that response if it was useful (including future members searching the archive)
C) Deny other contributors of the ability to build on that info, co-sign or even disagree so we can make our ideas better 

The working pros here give their time so they can have the maximum impact for younger players, asking for custom one off responses to your specific issue on a private channel undermines that

Thanks!

author: Slow Hand
content:
I'd like to say thank you to @everyone here. It's no overstatement to say that you *are* this server and the reason for it's success.

We've got a very special community that's been built up over our short history and this place would fall apart if each and every one of us wasn't maintaining the level of excellence, understanding, kindness, and great discourse that this place is known for. We've got something special here.

I love to see how welcoming you all are whenever we get someone new and how helpful we are at answering the questions of people at every stage of their journey. Hats off to the collective "we" and to the individuals who make this place great.

And finally, thank you to @oaklandmatt for creating such a place. Thank you for everything that you've made here and for giving us a place to thrive and come to know one another.

author: JakeTB
content:
Hey all. Just wanted to say how much I appreciate this community and attest to the quality of conversation here.

I put in my resignation notice at the day job today, and will be transitioning to music full-time in May. I genuinely don’t believe I could have done it without this place. You all challenge me in the best ways, and have helped me grow tremendously as a person and a professional.

I still don’t have it all sorted out, and I’m still fervently pursuing mentorship in any form I can find, but for now the work is paying the bills; something I thought I’d never be able to say.

Thank you all for being generous with your hard-earned wisdom. It really does make a difference.

(Sorry, got a bit sappy there 😅)

author: oaklandmatt
Slow Hand
content:
Hey @everyone. Our resident mixer and engineer @cian riordan made a badass post on Friday about his approach to mixing live drums. He even shared his template; great guy that he is. Did you catch it?

If not, which channel did he post it in? The hell if *I* know! Luckily we no longer have to trawl the Discord logs to locate it. His entire essay is now being hosted on the newly minted *Resources* section of the LWMR website.

In the coming weeks we’ll be filling this section in with some of the very best posts and nuggets of wisdom that have come through the LWMR server so far. No more brilliant posts lost forever in the torrent of people talking about Topping DACs or asking for a collab channel. Today we’re laying the foundations so that future generations might someday know how to make their 808s go *brrrrrrr*.

https://www.livewithmattrad.com/resources

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
So at the urging of Cian & Rauirí and a few other good friends, I took a full 3 months off when my daughter was born. During my paternity leave, my creative outlets were cooking, and photography. 

Photos are great cause you can snag a moment and then come back to it later to edit, cooking more difficult cause it takes time you might not always have. 

Well in typical captial C Creative fashion, i dug deep into it. I did a LOT of research and made some purchases and practiced a lot. Got some beautiful photos and captured some important memories. Really grateful for it. 

All that’s just backstory to say- everywhere else on the internet SUCKS. 

Reddit, Facebook, anywhere there are communities of people who are “trying to help,” it’s just full of tone deaf assholes with little info and a lot of bullshit to spew. And even the smart ones are 99% of the time tactless. 

Guys & girls, thank you for still being here. Best water cooler in the world: LWMR. 

Also I wish we had a photography channel.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Ok, let me throw out one more question that I love to ask people:

When you count silently from 1 to 10 in your head (1, 2, 3, 4, ... 10) how do you experience the numbers that are being counted?

Click 👂if you hear a voice speaking the numbers out loud.

Click 👁 if you see visual representation's of the numbers in your mind's eye. Like a numeric counter or numerals on a piece of paper.

Click 👤 if you feel a pulse or a sensation in your body with each number.

Click ❓if you experience something not mentioned. And please share.

author: sinaigimenez
content:
Today I got a reminder of how important love and care are in what we do. Just wanna give a shoutout to @Nomograph Mastering for all the wisdom shared here on that topic.

Long story short — I agreed to mix a track for an American rapper who had already been turned down by some A-list mixers, even though the guy had a decent budget. The reason was kinda obvious: he’s got a personality that leans toward OCD, with everything that comes with that — defensive tone in convos, super long mix notes, and weird stuff like thinking a file sounds different just because it was renamed. (I forgot to label one file as “ref. limited” like the previous versions, and even though it was literally the exact same file, he swore the “non-limited” one had a different top end.)

Stuff like that made me seriously consider walking away from the project like the others did — I could just feel the back-and-forth drama coming. But after my first instinct, I remembered a lot of what’s been talked about here: love, care, and being open to the music and the art. So I decided to try empathy instead of just being a jerk out of frustration.

And honestly? It worked. After taking a bit of time to really talk to him and show I genuinely wanted to help — not just as a mixer, but as a human — I learned he’s totally burnt out and running on fumes 'cause he just became a dad. And I totally get that, since my first kid was born a month ago too. That connection shifted the whole vibe. The next round of notes actually made sense, and we ended up approving the first mix by version 4 — which isn’t bad at all. Happy client, job done.

Not saying you should hang onto toxic clients, but it was a solid reminder: don’t always go with your first reaction. Sometimes just showing a little care  about the person on the other side can change everything. It did for me this time. And tbh, I don’t think I would’ve handled it this way if I hadn’t read some of the stuff shared here. So thanks, y’all. This place is gold.

author: cian riordan
content: Surreal to be recording rock music at this level, in this caliber room today… of all days. I had two real guiding lights in my engineering journey, Eric V was one of them, and it was life changing  to work under him. Steve was the other. Unfuckwithable engineering prowess paired with the sharpest, most searing wit and intelligence. RIP to one of the greatest of our time. I wouldn’t be doing this if it wasn’t for his influence.

content: just a quick moment of gratitude for this place. i abuse yall for notes on records that are important to me and it consistently leads to noticeable growth in my perspective on my own work. and just better results in the final records. every damn time. we all know it's not the easiest to mix your own productions, especially when an artist is so chill and trusting with whatever you do. this proves how essential it is to have that healthy back n forth of getting honest critique and notes. criticism to me is a sign of respect. anyways you all know this shit already nothing golden here just yapping the same old truths. major shout in particular to Noah, Cian, Edsel, both Joshes, Bradley, Kyle, Justin, I'm not even tagging you guys cuz I've already blown your phones up enough. also a major shoutout to rick and ryan from make believe who've taught me so much about their incredible plugins as I'm now using them on everything. just some thursday gratitude is all. thanks!!

Look, its 15 minutes to midnight, so I’m going to get this out of the way early:

author: BatMeckley
content:
Been working on this MPC Studio all day today, and was struck by how lucky I am to be a part of this server. Last night I had a question about an audio routing program and multiple people that are not on my payroll, they do not work for me or owe me anything, responded not just same day but within minutes with information that helped me get to where I was trying to go.

So many producers/writers/engineers/music makers/ dreamers are going to be better off, and way further along their paths, because of the wealth of knowledge and the generosity of the people on this discord, from the most seasoned mods to the newest noobs. And it’s entirely free. 

Thanks @oaklandmatt for putting this thing together. There’s always something new to learn and this is a rad place to learn it.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Sooooo.... It's come to my attention that not everyone has an internal monologue. A voice in their head. This is kind of wild to me. Supposedly as many as 50% of people don't have an inner monologue. 

It never occurred to me that people wouldn't, but I guess I shouldn't be surprised. My mind's eye is pretty lo-res, while some of my friends have the ability to visualize very detailed imagery in their heads.

Now I'm curious. Who here has an internal monologue and who does not?

Gimme a 👍 if you do have an internal monologue.
Gimme a 👎 if you don't have one.

author: BatMeckley
content: I’m going to get absolutely hammered for this, but, you can’t be afraid to suck. It’s ok to suck. Stop spending all your time analyzing how not to suck and just go out and suck. And then suck again. And then suck again, but a little bit less. And just bake into the equation that you’ll suck for probably 50-100 songs. Because every success is built on a ton of previous sucking. Even Michael Jordan got cut from his highschool basketball team cause he sucked. But no one got worse at something the more they did it. You’re not supposed to be good at something right away. You’re supposed to suck, until you finally don’t. But you get to the suck less phase by actually sucking lots.

author: BatMeckley
content: Here’s the public service announcement that it is 110% ok to just produce or mix music as a hobby and not as your primary source of income. You can still find it incredibly fulfilling and not even be particularly good at it. Just because it’s not paying your bills does not mean it’s not a worth while pursuit. Music is magic. It’s supposed to be fun.

author: Rollmottle
content:
Hey folks, here's a little context on why that channel is no longer visible to certain members. The @moderators have had a long-running discussion about the risk of a scam happening in the sales channel. As the server continues to scale, it’s only a matter of time and is the last thing we want to have happen. 

We’ve decided to restrict the sales channel to members who have been here 3 months or more and have been regularly active on the server. New members will no longer see the channel and will have to request access from one of the mods once they’ve been here longer than 3 months and have established themselves on the server. We’ve been looking for a bot that will help us automate this, but out of an abundance of caution, this was the simplest (free-est) solution for now.

author: bobby k
content:
About a week ago I was in here moping about how I had like one thing on the calendar for the entire month and it was freaking me out. you guys had really great feedback, and @Josh Bowman compared it to walking on an invisible path in Mario which is so spot on. It ended up being a major positive because I was able to say yes to several things that came up since (which included two of the coolest opportunities I’ve had all year, one with producing for a new fav artist of mine and the other with a band I listened to a ton as a kid). And everyone was so glad I was able to be as flexible as I was and make things happen with full dedication at short notice. 

All in all, hitting those scary moments where you’re broke and unbooked can be a rock solid motivator, and somehow yet again the universe is looking out for me. Didn’t even need to finish my soundbetter profile 😂

author: chrissorem
content:
Story time:  yesterday I received a text from a manager I supposedly know. He Said I have an artist that has a jazz album that needs mixed. He asked me can you text him? I thought to myself that’s not normally how this goes but sure..  so I texted and within an instant, he called me. He said.” did you look me up?” I said no I just texted you like I was asked. He said.” you should look me up.” he proceeded to tell me  he’s been signed to major label  for 25 years. Supposedly Warner brothers and followed with they gave him $600 to mix this album which then I said I’m sorry but I can’t help you.. he said “send me a number of someone who can mix a jazz album.” I sent him to a friend who I know it was hurting for work.. then he text me back about five minutes later and said this guy never mixed a jazz album before. Send me  somebody who mixed a jazz album preferably over 40. I sent him Al Schmitt’s contact and he responded to me. “All has  been dead for several years get with it man.”

there’s nothing to be learned here.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
...completely unrelated to anything  but on my mind this morning

Something I've said here (maybe too) often is that approaching the work in a loving way is a real unlock. Love being a quaity of a attention, a way of meeting things. It might not be obvious but it can start small and grow out embracing many more aspects of what we do

I mastered an album a few months back for a phenomenal indie artist, @Rob Domos and I both absolutely loved the music and the overall experience. The artist's team came back this week with a last minute request to remaster what was probably my favorite track with an added feature from a legacy artist. It's kind of mind bending how much better it is

Rob and I spent some time yesterday just appreciating that someone (the artist, manager, A&R?) actually thought up the idea of this feature and made it happen. I was so content with what it was but someone somewhere was like *"you know what would be sick ..."* and made it real. And now the world gets to receive something beyond what we could have imagined, something we didn't even know we needed

Just focussing our attention on that for 2 mins in the hall yesterday made the day better and put some gas in the tank. There are so many challenges in what we do, it really helps to take time to focus attention on the jewels strewn everywhere too. They are not always immediately obvious

author: NoahNeedleman
